item.title: Ticket #1748 (root-relative links should be converted to absolute in rss feeds) created
item.dc:creator: digitalgimpus
item.description:
currently bloggers may use relative links to link to a past post, or some other page in their site:

/archives/foo/bar

that is invalid in a feed, as all URI's need to be absolute (for rather obvious reasons).

The correct fix would be to find relative links in a post, and convert them to absolute.

This is important where full-text feeds are provided, as the links break. Some tools automatically assume and fix it, but some do not. feedvalidator.org says it's bad.

item.title: Ticket #1744 (XML-RPC API does not allow users with level-1 to post (as draft).) created
item.dc:creator: pidge
item.description:
This ticket applies with WP 1.5, 1.5.1.4, and 1.5.2.

According to the documentation:

â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/User_Levels

users with level one should be able to post as draft. This fine via WP admin page, but not implemented in xml-rpc layer.

Currently, the xml-rpc layer simply checks for user permissions by calling user_can_create_post (and user_can_edit_post etc).

The user_can_create_post (in the functions-post.php) checks to see if the user level is > 1. So, any user with level = 1 will not be able to post via xml-rpc api.

The functions-posts.php also has user_can_create_draft function, but this is not used by the xml-rpc layer, hence users with level one cannot post even as draft.

One thing I would like to propose is the following:

1) In the xml-rpc layer, always force the post_status to "draft" if the user level is one. This way, existing desktop clients can still post (in case the user forgot choose post-as-draft, or the client may not even support draft mode)

2) If the user is level 1 (or a level that does not allow the user to set the time), then ignore the date/time stamp sent in the post. Default to current date and time. (Again for compatibility with existing clients)

3) If user's level (e.g one) does not allow setting post categories, then ignore the categories if they are sent as part of the post struct.

3) Call user_can_create_draft funtion as well.

E.g. if (!user_can_create_post && !user_can_create_draft) {

return http 401 code.

}

The same would apply when setting categories or editing posts etc.

4) Return the post status (e.g. 'draft') value in method to calls getRecentPosts, getPost etc. E.g, return post attributes such as mt_convert_breaks, post_status, user_level, (draft/published), etc. so that the client app will have more information about the post.

  • pidge (www.zoundry.com)

item.title: Ticket #1743 (Massive code cleanup: functions.php) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
I did a massive cleanup on functions.php

I focused on things like:

  • spacing in "if" conditions
  • spacing between "if" and "("
  • multi spaces to tabs
  • elimination of brackets around one-line if ()s
  • tab and bracket matching

I'm not quite done, but it is a good start. I'll make another pass whenever I'm in an appropriately obsessive compulsive mood again, maybe working on some more meaty stuff, like if ( $foo == 1 ) to if ( 1 == $foo ) and stuff like that.
